Question_1.Context: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are substances that can easily evaporate and enter the atmosphere under normal conditions of temperature and pressure.
Question_1.Question: Which of the following is a standard method to evaluate human exposure to VOCs?
Question_1.A: Direct reading with a portable gas chromatograph
Question_1.B: Sampling the air on sorbents followed by liquid extraction and gas chromatograph analysis
Question_1.C: Using a mass spectrometer in an open field
Question_1.D: Real-time monitoring with a photoionization detector
Question_1.Source: The standard method to evaluate human exposure to volatile organic compounds (VOCs) is in general performed by sampling the air on sorbents followed by liquid extraction and detection using laboratory gas chromatograph (GC).

Question_2.Context: In the analysis of VOCs, the use of certain solvents can add risk factors due to their toxicity.
Question_2.Question: Which toxic solvent is commonly employed in the conventional method of VOC analysis that adds a risk factor?
Question_2.Source: The conventional method is time and labor intensive and employs a toxic solvent which adds a risk factor as well as waste.

Question_3.Context: Gas chromatographs (GC) equipped with flame ionization detectors (FID) are used to detect and quantify organic compounds in various samples.
Question_3.Question: What is the main advantage of using a portable GC with FID for VOC analysis?
Question_3.A: It requires a large volume of sample for analysis
Question_3.B: It allows near real-time, in-situ analysis
Question_3.C: It is less sensitive compared to laboratory GC
Question_3.D: It can only be used in laboratory settings
Question_3.Source: Hence, there have been increasing demands for portable GC instruments which allow near real-time, in-situ analysis.

Question_4.Context: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) can pose health risks upon exposure, and certain compounds are classified based on their carcinogenic potential.
Question_4.Question: How is ethylbenzene classified in terms of its carcinogenic potential?
Question_4.D: Group 3 - Not classifiable as to its carcinogenicity to humans
Question_4.Source: Ethylbenzene is a possible carcinogen classified as Group 2B by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC).

Question_5.Context: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) can be found in many industrial processes and products, and their excessive exposure can lead to various health issues.
Question_5.Question: Which of the following health effects is NOT typically associated with acute exposure to VOCs?
Question_5.Source: Excessive, acute exposure to VOCs can cause eye, nose and throat irritation, nausea, and dizziness and chronic exposure to high concentration can cause liver/kidney disease, central nervous system (CNS) damage, and cancer.

Question_6.Context: In gas chromatography, the choice of column can affect the separation and analysis of compounds.
Question_6.Question: What is the main purpose of using dual columns with different characteristics in a gas chromatograph?
Question_6.A: To increase the complexity of the analysis
Question_6.B: To reduce the sensitivity of the instrument
Question_6.C: To provide high sensitivity with selectivity for compounds that co-elute
Question_6.D: To make the instrument more portable
Question_6.Source: Dual columns, with different characteristics when dedicated to the same atmospheric analysis, enables a GC analyzer to provide very high sensitivity with selectivity for compounds that co-elute.

Question_7.Context: The detection limits of analytical instruments are crucial for determining the smallest quantity of a substance that can be reliably measured.
Question_7.Question: What is the limit of detection for BTEX compounds using the prototype GC with dual FID?
Question_7.Source: The protoGC had default dual columns each connected to its individual FID for which the dynamic range was 5,000 and limit of detection for BTEX was 1 ppb in air.

Question_8.Context: Calibration of analytical instruments is necessary to ensure accurate measurements of analytes.
Question_8.Question: What is typically used to calibrate a gas chromatograph for VOC analysis?
Question_8.A: A series of known concentrations of nitrogen
Question_8.B: A single standard solution of the analyte
Question_8.C: A series of dilutions of the analyte in a solvent
Question_8.Source: Three calibration standards of 2.5, 10, and 25 µg/ml were prepared for calibration according to the manufacturer’s instructions.

Question_9.Context: The correlation coefficient is a statistical measure that describes the extent to which two variables are linearly related.
Question_9.Question: What does a correlation coefficient (r) close to 1 between two methods of VOC analysis indicate?
Question_9.B: A perfect negative linear relationship between the methods
Question_9.C: A strong positive linear association between the methods
Question_9.D: The methods are identical in every aspect
Question_9.Source: The results of protoGC correlated well with the conventional method (r = 0.991–0.999), indicating that protoGC has comparable performance with the conventional method within the test conditions.

Question_10.Context: Statistical analysis can be used to compare the performance of different analytical methods.
Question_10.Question: What statistical test can be used to determine whether mean concentrations of VOCs are significantly different between two analytical methods?
Question_10.Source: A two-way ANOVA was performed at each target concentration to examine the effect of method (i.e., protoGC and conventional) and analyte (i.e., toluene, ethylbenzene, and o-, m-, and p-xylene) on mean concentrations to mainly determine whether the mean concentrations were statistically different between methods as well as analytes.
